awd_titl_txt: Creating Pathways for Big Data Careers
awd_abstract_narration:
The quantity of digital data created globally is growing exponentially, and workers in many professions need skills to organize and analyze the deluge of data that confronts them. To address the urgent need for workers who have "big data" skills, the Oceans of Data Institute (ODI) of the Education Development Center will work with four community colleges that are leaders in the area of big data, data science, and data analytics to create a career pathway model for big data careers, with special attention to the "middle skill" jobs that can be filled by graduates of community college programs. Subject matter experts representing a variety of professional fields will identify the entry-level, middle-level, and high-level big data skills, knowledge, and behaviors that are needed in the workplace, and these skills, knowledge, and behaviors will then be organized and aligned with big data jobs. ODI and partners Bunker Hill Community College (Massachusetts), Normandale Community College (Minnesota), Johnson County Community College (Kansas), and Sinclair Community College (Ohio) will work together to design the big data career pathway model. They will document pathways to these careers via a system of stackable credentials that identify associate degrees, certificates, and four-year programs leading to employment. Each college will adapt the pathway model to fit the big data labor demand in its geographic region. To build the capacity of faculty to teach big data skills, Bunker Hill Community College will leverage its relationship with the Broadening Advanced Technological Education Connections (BATEC) center to deliver appropriate professional development for faculty. ODI and the partner colleges will disseminate the project's products to a national audience of community colleges (including minority serving institutions and tribal colleges) and business/industry representatives hiring for big data positions.

The methodology that the project team will use to define the "Middle-Skill Big Data-Enabled Specialist" (MSBDES) has been used successfully to define other emerging occupations, has been widely validated, and has been used internationally to identify the skills needed by front-line workers. The project's products will include an occupational profile of the MSBDES, which will articulate the big data skills, knowledge, and behaviors expected by industry. The profile will be paired with rubrics that describe proficient performance of the big data middle skills. The profile and performance rubrics will provide an assessment framework that will assist community college faculty in evaluating student proficiency. These materials, along with the stackable credentials, will guide other community colleges seeking to develop big data courses and programs.

por.por_cntn:
Recipient Organization: EDC

PIs: Joyce Malyn-Smith, Principal Investigator; Jaimie Mahoney, Co-PI; Paul Hansford, Co-PI; Randall Kochevar, Co-PI; Suzanne Smith, Co-PI.

To meet the rapidly growing demand for middle skilled data workers, EDC collaborated with Bunker Hill CC (MA), Sinclair CC (OH), Normandale CC (MN) and Johnson County CC (KS) to create a national career pathway model for data science by developing and/or strengthening degree and certificate programs in data analytics that can be replicated in other community colleges across the country. The project received supplemental funding to conduct a study tour of European Work-based Learning Models for Data Science.

 

The project developed: 1)  the Profile of the Data Practitioner, articulating industry expectations for the skills, knowledge and behaviors of middle skilled data workers; 2) assessment guidelines  (Rubrics) tied to the Profile;  3) a Data Science Program Development Model outlining steps in developing data science programs in community colleges; 4)Tools for Building a Big Data Career Path, guiding schools in designing and implementing career pathways in data science; 5) a Stackable Credentials Model for institutions to build on existing programs and move toward higher level certification or degrees; and 6) a data science Community of Practice (CoP) consisting of 70+ community college faculty/members. 

 

As a result, participating colleges developed four Associates Degree programs and seven Certificate programs in Data Analytics, and offered 23 data courses. Three articulation agreements were developed extending the pathway into Bachelor's and Master's Degree programs. Across institutions, 500+ students participated in data education program activities.

 

Products developed by this project have been tested by nine participating colleges as resources for developing data analytics programs aimed at educating the middle skilled data workforce. All materials are accessible through EDC's Oceans of Data Website at http://oceansofdata.org/.  The Profile of the Data Practitioner is used by colleges to build data science programs, and the Gap Analysis Tools within the "Tools for Building a Big Data Career Path," serve to align curriculum with local industry needs. Faculty from this project now serve as mentors to community colleges developing data analytics programs through NSF ATE #1902568 Mentoring to Support Designing and Launching of New Data Science Career Pathways at Community Colleges.

 

EDC also led a learning exchange with European academic institutions and their business partners who have established Work-based Learning models in data science. During this exchange, faculty shared their work, learned of European efforts and initiatives, and began to explore strategies for integrating work-based learning activities into their career pathways. This tour provided participants with new perspectives on their work, understanding of what others are doing in similar academic and workforce environments, and strategies to improve their own programs here in the U.S.

The project has enabled these goals by providing access to industry experts who worked in tandem with the college partners to build the Profile of the Data Practitioner, ensuring that the skills and knowledge needed by industry were embedded within the college data programs. Connecting with study tour models of workforce education has strengthened participants' knowledge of education programs effective at graduating skilled workers. Finally, by maintaining a connection to college partners named in this grant, including them as mentors and advisors in the next NSF ATE grant (#1902568), EDC has built a lasting cohort of colleges invested in the support of mid-level data analytics degrees. The project has expanded this core relationship through the CoP , which includes more than 40 community colleges developing their own data programs. 

 

The momentum begun by this project has expanded the network of community colleges engaged in program development for data analytic/science.  The project's growing pool of mentors works with mentee colleges to develop new data analytics programs. This spread helps fuel community colleges as the workforce engine preparing the next generation of middle skilled data science workers. 

 

The products developed by this project help save community colleges time and money.  The project's ongoing CoP  is a cost free source of program development guidance, as colleges discuss common challenges and share successes and resources through meetings, a newsletter, and a listserv.  These conversations resulted in a resource collection of shared program development tools for 2- and 4- year institutions aimed at developing data coursework and/or programs: Data Science Textbooks, Tools, and Certifications.  

 

Overall, our evaluation suggests that this project was very valuable to institutions in that it provided resources and space to 1) strategize how to address the labor needs of data enabled workers and appropriate training, especially at the Associates Degree and Certificate levels, 2) explore the institutional buy-in and impact related to developing programs or courses, 3) interact with industry to gain first-hand knowledge of current and future labor skill needs, and 4) interact with other similar institutions grappling with these issues.

 


Last Modified: 12/21/2022
Modified by: Joyce Malyn-Smith
